Chapter 1, Section 3: The Three Analyses, Part 1. The nature, bases, and elements of the four aggregates have already been explained.
The nature, bases, and elements of the fifth aggregate of consciousness will now be revealed.
Verse:
Consciousness refers to each distinct cognition, which is also called the base of mind,
And the seven elements should be known, with the six consciousnesses transforming into the mind.
Discussion:
Consciousness refers to distinct cognition, which means it only generally grasps the characteristics of objects.
Each generally grasps the characteristics of its own objects, called each distinct cognition.

This means that although eye consciousness has many objects such as form present, it only grasps form and does not grasp sound, etc., it only grasps blue, etc., and not blue, etc., nor is it agreeable or disagreeable, nor is it male or female, nor is it a person or a stump, nor is it gain or loss, etc.
Just as eye consciousness only grasps the general characteristics of its own objects, so should the other consciousnesses be understood accordingly.
Other masters say:
Who would attribute agency to the nature of dharmas? To refute the notion that there is an experiencer separate from consciousness.
Where else have we seen agency attributed only to the nature of dharmas?
Because we see it said that the moving shadow is the mover. Even though there is no movement in the case of arising without interval in different places, still it is said that the mover moves.

Consciousness is also like this. Even though there is no movement in the case of arising in a series with different objects, still it is said that the experiencer experiences, because it is able to experience objects. This is also without error.
How do we know this?
Because we see the refutation of agency elsewhere.
As the World-Honored One told PÄrÄyaá¹‡ika:
I never say there is an experiencer.
There are also those who say:
A moment is called the nature of dharmas, a series is called the agent.
What is established by one's own mind will be further revealed in the chapter on the arising of thought.
This consciousness is generally said to be three in terms of time, and is divided into six in terms of the specific faculties on which it depends.

You should know that this consciousness aggregate, when classified in terms of sense bases, is called the mind sense base, and when classified in terms of sense fields, is called the seven consciousnesses.
The term â€œandâ€ in the verse indicates that one is divided into two, and that each consciousness is classified in terms of sense bases and sense fields.
What are the seven consciousnesses?
They are the six consciousnesses and the mind. That is, the eye consciousness element up to the mental consciousness element.
These six consciousnesses are transformed into the mind sense base. You should know that these classifications of aggregates, sense bases, and sense fields include all dharmas without exception.
Here you should consider the following:
If the consciousness aggregate is called the seven mental sense bases, as previously stated, the consciousness aggregate is divided into six in terms of the specific faculties on which it depends.
Now, apart from the six consciousnesses, what dharma is called the mind sense base?
There is no other dharma.
In this regard, a verse says:
The six consciousnesses are the immediately past mind.
The treatise says:
The six consciousnesses, immediately after having perished, are able to generate subsequent consciousnesses, and are therefore called the mind element.
Because of the difference in time, there is no error in establishing them separately.
They are like a son and fruit, which are established as a father and seed.
If this is so, then the substance of the elements should be only seventeen or only twelve, because they include each other.
Why are the eighteen elements established?
The verse says:
In order to establish the sixth support, one should know the eighteen elements.
The treatise says:
Just as the five consciousnesses have separate eyes, etc., as supports for the five elements, the sixth consciousness, i.e., mental consciousness, has no separate support.
Just as there is no meaning for consciousness to arise apart from its object, the same is true of its support. Consciousness cannot arise without a support.
In order to establish this support, the mind element is spoken of.
In this way, the supports, the supported, and objects should be known as each consisting of six, and the elements are established as eighteen.
How can that which has already perished be called the support of present consciousness?
Because it is a proximate condition for the arising of present consciousness.
Although there is form, eye consciousness can only be produced in dependence on the eye.
In the same way, although there is an object-support, a subsequent consciousness can only be produced in dependence on a previous moment of mind that has just ceased.

Therefore, the previous statement that the mind that has just ceased is the manas is in order to exclude the mind of the previous moment that has ceased with an interval, because although it has been heard, it has not yet been produced.
On the basis of this, the six consciousnesses that have just ceased without interval are the support of the present consciousness and are called the mind sense base.

Or, the present consciousness is in the process of accomplishing the function of support, and the past [consciousness] has already become the condition as cause, and it is also able to take a result in the present.
Although it is produced in dependence on that, it is not said to be a mental activity because it is not necessarily of the same kind as the mind.
The aggregates, the appropriated aggregates, the sense bases, and the elements have been explained.
Herein, the meaning of inclusion should be considered:
The aggregates totally include all conditioned dharmas, the appropriated aggregates only include all that is contaminated, and the sense bases and elements totally include all dharmas.
The five aggregates and unconditioned dharmas are called all dharmas.
The specific inclusion is like this. We should now discuss the general inclusion.
A verse says:
All dharmas are generally included by one aggregate, one base, and one element.
They include their own nature, not others, because they are apart from the nature of others.
The treatise says:
One aggregate refers to form, one base refers to mind, and one element refers to dharmas. These three generally include the five aggregates and unconditioned dharmas.
Generally means the meaning of collection.
The word generally is used to let people know that there are three generally included dharmas, not just one each.
Other schools hold that inclusion means including others, because it is said in various places that the others include the others.

For example, it is said that the three aggregates include the eight factors of the noble path. If they only included their own nature, the aggregate of wisdom would only include right view, not right thought and right effort;
the aggregate of concentration would only include right concentration, not right mindfulness.
Since the sutras do not say it this way, we know that dharmas only include the nature of others.
This interpretation is not correct, because there is no fixed reason.

If it includes other natures, what is the fixed reason that the aggregate of discernment only includes correct thought and correct effort, and does not include correct mindfulness and correct meditation, or other dharmas?

If it is said that this inclusion also has a fixed reason, namely that correct thought and correct effort are by nature vigorous and can include the dharmas of discernment, mindfulness, meditation, etc., but are incompatible with the characteristic of discernment;
mindfulness includes meditation, but is not the same as thought, etc.
In that case, it would only include its own nature, because it does not include dharmas with different characteristics.

All dharmas, when compared with each other, have no characteristics that are not different. If it is allowed that they are included when they resemble each other to some extent, then all dharmas should be allowed to include all dharmas.
Why is it not the case that, just as they are associated with other natures, not all are associated with everything?
In the same way, it should be allowed that other natures are included, but not that all are included in everything.

This is not a proper analogy. Associates are only dharmas that have objects, and they are mutually similar in that they are associated with the same object, the same time, the same support, the same aspect, the same class, and so on. This is the meaning of association, and not all dharmas are associates.
As for the meaning of inclusion, it is common to all dharmas. What is the definite reason that only this includes that and does not include other dharmas?
Therefore, all dharmas should include all dharmas.
Because the various material dharmas and the dharmas not directly associated with mind are mutually dissimilar in that they do not have the same object, and so on. Therefore, they are not associates.
Inclusion is not like this.
If inclusion means the inclusion of other natures, why does the eye not include the ear, and so on?
The same is true of the mutual inclusion of acquisition and so on.
If this is so, why does a scripture say the following?
Here, that which is similar is metaphorically said to be included. That is, correct thought and correct effort are both categorized as wisdom, because they are similar to correct view.
Correct mindfulness is categorized as samÄdhi, because it is similar to correct samÄdhi.
They are metaphorically said to be included.

If this is so, then why do various scriptures say that the five roots of faith, etc., are included in the root of discernment, and that we use the four means of conversion to convert our followers, and that the center of a pavilion is the place where the rafters are gathered?
The world also says that the two doors are gathered by the two bolts, that the spokes are gathered by the wheel rim, and that the threads gather the cloth.
What do these expressions mean?
All these expressions are provisional and figurative, meaning that they are gathered by the power of skillful means, which attracts and holds them together.
The statements in the scriptures that one thing gathers other things are temporary and provisional, because they are established in dependence on other things.
Gathering is established in dependence on causes, and the meaning is the same as non-gathering.

Moreover, if you admit that dharmas definitely gather other natures, then when one dharma arises, all dharmas should arise, and when one dharma ceases, all dharmas should cease. This would increase the fault of non-desirability.
When one part is cut off, the five parts should be cut off, and the cultivation of superior antidotes would be useless.

Seeing these and other faults, the masters of our school say that it is the nature of dharmas that subsumes them. The statement that this subsumption is the nature of dharmas is the ultimate explanation, because it does not depend on anything else.
Subsumption does not depend on causes. This is true subsumption, because dharmas always subsume their own natures.
How do we know that they do not subsume other natures?
Because all dharmas are apart from other natures.

That is to say, the nature of the eye faculty is apart from the natures of the ear and other faculties. It cannot be logically said that it subsumes that which is apart from it. Therefore we know that dharmas only subsume their own natures.
In this way, the eye faculty only subsumes the form aggregate, because the eye sense base, eye element, truth of suffering, truth of the cause of suffering, etc., are of its nature.
It does not subsume the other aggregates, other sense bases, elements, etc., because they are apart from its nature.
In this way, the other dharmas should be considered as appropriate.
The subsumption based on nature should be considered in this way.
Under which element are the two faculties of male and female subsumed?
What is the reason for suddenly giving rise to doubt about this?
The masters of other schools say:
Because they are not the body faculty, they are not included in the body element.
Therefore one might doubt this.
One should abandon this doubt and determine that they are included in the body element, because their function differs from that of the body.
How can the elements be the same?
Because the class, object, and consciousness are the same, they are included in one element.
As for the class being the same, the male and female faculties are the same class as the body.
Because the objects are the same, one knows that the class is the same.
The male and female faculties and the body have the same tactile objects.
When touched in the throat, one feels it in the eyes, nose, and throat, but not in other places. How can it be a different body faculty?
The same object is shown by the same consciousness, because all are the basis of body consciousness.
The meaning of predominance differs, therefore separate faculties are established.

That is, because the male and female faculties are the same class as the body, have the same object, and have the same consciousness, although they are the same in place and element, because the meaning of predominance differs, therefore two separate faculties are established.
Just as the eleven faculties, although the same in place and element, have different meanings of predominance and are established as separate faculties.
The eye, ear, and nose faculties each depend on two places. Why are the substance of the realms not considered to be many?
Because two are combined into one, there are only eighteen.
Why are two combined into one realm?
The verse says:
Because type, object, and consciousness are the same, although two, the substance of the realms is one.
The treatise says:
Although the eye, ear, and nose faculties each have two places, because type, etc. are the same, they are combined into one realm.
As for the same type, they are the same in being of the nature of the eye.
As for the same object, they are the same in having form as their object.
As for the same consciousness, they are the basis of eye consciousness.
The ear and nose are also like this, so one realm is established.
Since the substance of the realms is already one, why are the places two?
The verse says:
However, in order to make the body beautiful, the eye, etc. each produce two.
The treatise says:
In order for the supported body to be beautiful, although the substance of the realms is one, it produces in two places.
If the eye and ear faculties only produced one each, and the nose had no two nostrils, the body would not be beautiful.
This explanation is not correct. How can camels, cats, owls, etc., which are so ugly, be considered beautiful?
Therefore, the various faculties are born with different arrangements and distinctions, depending on causes and conditions.

Such distinctions in causes and conditions may be obstructed, or two may not be born, just like the body faculty, head, neck, belly, back, hands, feet, etc. The different arrangements and kinds are like this, and one should not doubt or object.

They also depend on causes and conditions. Such distinctions in causes and conditions may be obstructed, or something different may be born, so the limbs of snakes, etc. have joints. Moreover, one sees that their tongues are not born as one, so the different arrangements of the faculties arise depending on causes and conditions, not for the sake of beautifying the body.
If that is so, why is it said that the eye faculties, etc. are born in two places each for the sake of beauty?
This has a separate meaning, not for the sake of beautifying the body.

It is commonly seen in the world that when the function of something is complete and perfect, it is also said to be beautiful. If the eyes and so forth were each located in one place, the functions of seeing, hearing, and smelling would all be unclear. When each has two, the function arises clearly. Therefore, this statement that it is beautiful is precisely for the sake of causing the function to be superior.
The inclusion of the aggregates, sense bases, and elements has already been explained. Now we will explain their meanings.
In the known realm, the aggregates include conditioned phenomena, and the sense bases and elements also include unconditioned phenomena.
Why is this so?
In the known realm, it is sometimes called aggregates, sometimes called sense bases and elements, because the three meanings of aggregates, sense bases, and elements are different.
What are the different meanings?
Verse:
Accumulation, means of birth, and family lineage are the meanings of aggregates, sense bases, and elements.
Treatise:
The meaning of accumulation is the meaning of aggregates, the meaning of means of birth is the meaning of sense bases, and the meaning of family lineage is the meaning of elements.
Why is it known that the meaning of accumulation is aggregates?
Because it is said in the sÅ«tras.
As a scripture says:
All forms, whether past, future, or present, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near, are all briefly gathered into one aggregate, called the form aggregate.
This scripture shows that the meaning of aggregate is that of a heap.
Why do we know that the meaning of Äyatana is that of a door?
Because of the etymological explanation.
Ä€yatana means a place of birth, because mind and mental factors are born and grow in it, and it is called an Äyatana because it is able to give rise to and develop their activity.
As a scripture says:
Brahmans should know that the eye is the door, only for seeing forms.
This scripture only proves that the meaning of door is six. However, mind and mental factors have twelve doors, therefore a scripture says:
The eye and form as conditions give rise to eye consciousness, the union of the three is contact, and together with it arise feeling, conceptualization, and volition.

In the same way, the mental faculty and dharmas as conditions produce mental consciousness, and the union of the three is contact, which arises simultaneously with feeling, conceptualization, and volition.
Other masters say:
Because mind and so on are born and grow by relying on these, they are called bases.
Why do we know that the meaning of family is element?
Because it is similar to the meaning of family in the world.
Just as there are many families of realgar, yellow orpiment, red clay, and arsenic in one mountain, it is called the many elements.
In the same way, there are eighteen kinds of families of dharmas in one body or one continuity, called the eighteen elements.
Just as there are mines of realgar and so on in that mountain, which are called families.
In the same way, there are families of dharmas that are the source of mind and mental factors in this body, which are called families.
If that is so, the meanings of base and element should overlap, because they both have the meaning of being the source of mind and mental factors.
For this reason, the meaning of family should be explained separately.
Like orpiment, etc., which are different from each other in substance and kind, and are therefore called species.
In the same way, the eye, etc., are different from each other in substance and kind, and are therefore called species.
If this is so, then the mind-organ is not different from the six consciousnesses in substance and kind, and should not be a separate realm.
This objection is not valid, because the support and the supported are different in substance and kind.
Some say:
Because the time periods are established differently.
There are also those who say:
The six are prior to the mind, and the mind is not prior to the six, so there is a great difference.
Although the substance of all realms extends to the three time periods, the different names are established according to the stage. For this reason, it is said that the six are prior to the mind.

How can it be said that the six are prior to the mind, when the future mind and the six have not yet been distinguished?ğŸ”½If the meaning of the aggregates is explained as the meaning of a collection, then the aggregates are not real, because a collection is provisional.
This objection is not valid, because the meaning is established based on the collection, but the collection is not the meaning.
The meaning is the distinction of the real entities. An aggregate is not a real entity.

This explanation shows that the sÅ«tra has a great purport, namely, that just as an aggregate is spoken of, apart from the basis of the aggregate, there is no separately existing real entity of the aggregate that can be obtained.

In the same way, apart from form, etc., it should not be sought that there is a real entity of a self, because a self is spoken of as a convention in the continuity of the aggregates, just as in the world there is an aggregate.
If a self does not really exist, and if the aggregates really exist, what meaning does the sÅ«tra show?

Do not let those who are to be taught know that the various kinds of dharmas such as form, etc., are innumerable and distinguished in the three periods of time, and that each is an aggregate, and that the aggregates are then limitless, and then they will become discouraged, thinking, â€œHow can I thoroughly know and forever end these limitless aggregates?â€
In order to encourage them, although the aggregates are limitless, they are the same in kind, and therefore they are generally said to be one.
Moreover, the foolish give rise to the idea of a unity in regard to many aggregates and give rise to the grasping of a self.

In order to eliminate the notion of a single whole, it is said that within a single aggregate there are many parts. It is not to show that the five aggregates such as form are composed of many dharmas and are therefore provisional and not real.
Moreover, a single ultimate atom is included in the three times, etc. It is analyzed by wisdom and briefly made into a single aggregate.
Although the aggregates are indeed aggregates, the real meaning is established. The same is true for other dharmas, so the aggregates are not provisional.

Moreover, because it is said that within each separately arising dharma there are also aggregates, the aggregates are definitely not provisional. It is like saying that the feeling that arises together is called the feeling aggregate, and the conception is called the conception aggregate. The other explanations are like the sÅ«tras.
Because they arise together at all times, although the aggregates are distinct, the meaning of aggregation is established.
Other masters say:
The meaning of skandha is the meaning of divisible sections, because all conditioned dharmas have past, future, and present divisible sections.
The SÅ«tra master decisively determines that this explanation goes against the sÅ«tras. I now say that is not so, because it does not contradict principle.
How can the two meanings of the aggregates and the bases not go beyond the sÅ«tras? Why do you take them as correct? What is the reason?
Only in the meaning of the aggregates do you seek the evidence of the sÅ«tras. In the meaning of the bases and elements, you only explain them according to reason and never seek the sÅ«tras.
Observing these words, it seems you are exclusively partisan. Therefore, it should be like that, according to reason, without contradiction.
Why is it so?
The World-Honored One, regarding the objects of cognition, spoke of them in three ways through the doors of the aggregates, etc.
The verse says:
Because of the three kinds of stupidity, faculties, and delight, the three, aggregates, bases, and elements, are spoken of.
The treatise says:

Although the purport of the Well-Gone One is extremely difficult to know, according to reason, it seems to be like this. It is said that the disciples have three kinds of stupidity, faculties, and delight each, and the Well-Gone One, following them, speaks of the three kinds of teachings of the aggregates, bases, and elements.
Delight refers to understanding. The three are each three.

The sentient beings to be transformed have three kinds of stupidity. Some are stupid about the mental factors and generally grasp them as the self, some are only stupid about form, and some are stupid about form and mind.
The faculties are also of three kinds, namely sharp, medium, and dull.
The pleasure is also of three kinds, namely pleasure in extensive, medium, and brief texts.
For the sake of those to be converted, the Well-Gone One expounds the three, aggregates, bases, and elements, in this order.

The master of the sutra has said here that this is still insufficient, because the disciples have already transcended attention, have already familiarized themselves with practice, and the initial cultivation of activities is different in the three stages;
Because of the three differences in the faults of bearing arrogance, grasping what belongs to the self, and being confused about the basis and conditions of consciousness;
Because of the three differences in the illnesses of relying on life, wealth, and family to give rise to arrogance.
For these and other reasons, the World-Honored One expounded the three, aggregates, bases, and elements, in this order.
The elder said:

It is said that the aggregates are expounded in order to clarify the characteristics of the differences in the grasped single wholes, the bases are expounded in order to clarify the characteristics of the differences in objects and the possessors of objects, and the elements are expounded in order to clarify the characteristics of the differences in objects, possessors of objects, and the consciousnesses that arise from them.
Now, let's discuss the gate of location. How is the universal establishment of objects and the characteristics of objects established?
Here, the five roots such as the eye and the mind root are not discussed because they are not the nature of objects.

However, all dharmas are the objects of the mind root. This is not a universal explanation of the objects of the mind in establishing the gate of location, but only because seven dharmas are said to be the objects of the mind. As a sutra says:
Bhiká¹£us, you should know that dharmas refer to the external sense bases, which are not included in the eleven sense bases.

Also, it is said everywhere that dharmas are the objects of the mind, so it is said that in the [gate of] location, it seems that the universal establishment of objects and the characteristics of objects is not established.
Those who have this to say here again say:

As a sutra says, The mind and dharmas serve as conditions to give rise to mental consciousness, it is said that all dharmas are the objects of the mind. They only have words, but there is no reason or teaching.
If this must be so, what is called the definite establishment of the characteristics of location?
First, the non-universal establishment of objects and the characteristics of objects, the error is the same as before.
Also, the elder says:
Because there is no dharma that is not the object of mental consciousness, all are included in the dharma realm.
If this is so, then you should establish only one dharma realm, because all dharmas are the objects of mental consciousness. This is mere words, without any definite evidence.

Again, they say that although there is really only one realm, it is given the other eleven names according to the differences in the characteristics of the one realm. That is, the first, the eye realm, is also called the dharma realm, up to the mental realm, which is also called the dharma realm. The last, the dharma realm, is only called the dharma realm.
If this is so, then you violate the sÅ«tra that distinguishes the realms, as that sÅ«tra says:
Bhiká¹£us, you should know that dharmas are the external realm, which is not included in the eleven realms.
Also, it is said in various places that dharmas are the objects of mental consciousness.
There is nowhere that says the first eleven realms are called the dharma realm. Therefore, you cannot say that although they are all the dharma realm,
in that sÅ«tra, according to the separate dharma realm, it says that dharmas not included in the eleven realms are called the dharma realm. Therefore, their words are mere self-concoction.
Moreover, although they establish objects and the possessor of objects, they are extremely confused.
The five [sense consciousnesses] take their own objects, and the mental [consciousness] takes all [objects]. What confusion is there?
The possessor of objects is the object, and the object is the possessor of objects. Isn't this confusion?
Because they do not understand which is the possessor of objects and which is the object here, they are very confused.
I see this meaning in this sÅ«tra, which is explained to show the difference between the basis that is not mixed and the object that is the possessor of objects.
What is the purpose of this?
It is to abandon the grasping of self.
The proponents of the doctrine of self falsely say:
I am the seer, and so on, up to the knower. This self is the basis of pleasure and so on.
This sÅ«tra shows that there are many dharmas with functions, and it shows that there is no single dharma called the seer, and so on, up to the basis.
For this reason, although all dharmas are the objects of the mind, they are not common objects.
Only that which is the object is established as the object of the mind. Only in relation to this is the mind established as the possessor of objects.

We fear that they will say that this is a different idea from what we have explained. There is a place where dharmas exist, but the substance of that place is only the object. There is also a place that has objects but is not the support.
Or, this place and the mental faculty are established as having objects, because it is the support. There is no error in this.
Although the eye, etc., and the mental faculty have the meaning of having objects that are not common to all, they are not only objects.
The five sense bases of form, etc., are only objects, but they do not have the meaning of having objects that are not common to all.
The five sense faculties of eye, etc., have no other objects. The objects of form, etc., are called not common. In relation to these objects, the name having objects is used.
Here, the word base is said to be the six, such as the eye, that are the support. The six, such as form, are said to be the objects.
It is said that they are bases because they manifest as conditions that give rise to and nourish different dharmas.
Based on this principle, the name base is explained. It is called a base because it can give rise to and nourish the mind and mental factors.
Therefore, the bases are said to be established in order to have objects that are not mixed and to have objects that are not confused. They have a function.
I see this meaning in this sÅ«tra.
Those who examine the Dharma should further contemplate:
Why are two dharmas established separately as the aggregates of feeling and conception among all mental factors?
The Venerable PÄrÅ›va said:
The World-Honored One has realized and established the dharmas, and one should not question him.
Or it is said there is a reason. The verse says:
Because they are the roots of disputes, the causes of birth and death, and the sequential causes,
Among all mental factors, feeling and conception are established as separate aggregates.
The treatise says:
The roots of disputes in the world are roughly of two kinds: namely, attachment to desires and indulgence in them, and attachment to views and indulgence in them.

The first arises from feeling, and the latter arises from conception. Because of the power of indulging in feelings, one becomes attached to desires. Because of the power of inverted conceptions, one becomes attached to views.
Moreover, the dharmas of birth and death have feeling and conception as their most excellent causes. Because one delights in feelings and grasps inverted conceptions.
The practitioner of love and views transmigrates in the cycle of birth and death due to these two causes, which will be explained later.
The order of the causes should be known, and therefore feeling and conceptualization are established separately as aggregates.
The order of the causes will be discussed immediately below.

Moreover, feeling and conceptualization are the fundamental causes for the arising of the two defiled dharmas of love and views, because each is separately manifested as a name for a station of consciousness, and because the cessation of these two is relied upon to establish the concentration of cessation.
For these and other reasons of various kinds, why is the unconditioned said to be included in the bases and elements, but not in the aggregates?
A verse says:
The aggregates do not include the unconditioned, because it is not appropriate.
The treatise says:
If the unconditioned dharmas are said to be aggregates, it is not reasonable to establish them as the fifth or a sixth aggregate, because it contradicts the meaning.
Why is this?
They are not form, up to and not consciousness, and therefore they are not included in the five.

The meaning of aggregate is that of a heap. Unconditioned dharmas are not aggregates because, unlike form, etc., they have no distinctions of past, future, etc., and one cannot speak of a heap of unconditioned dharmas. Therefore they are not a sixth aggregate.
Also, unconditioned dharmas are not aggregates because they are not a basis for the perversions, nor are they a means of eliminating them.

The conditioned aggregates are said to be a basis for the perversions, and the unconditioned aggregates are said to be a means of eliminating them. Unconditioned dharmas have nothing to do with these two meanings, and therefore it is not proper to establish them as aggregates.
There is an opinion that
unconditioned dharmas are a cessation of the aggregates and therefore cannot be called aggregates, just as a broken earthenware pot is no longer called a pot.

The author of the commentary criticizes this opinion:ğŸ”½The same error would occur in the case of the sense bases and elements, because the sense bases and elements that are a cessation would not be sense bases and elements. This would contradict the accepted doctrine that the aggregates are the basis of the idea of a living being.

When one enters the stage of no residue, all the aggregates cease suddenly, but this is not the case with the sense bases and elements, because the sense bases and elements are not the basis of the idea of a living being. Only the arising of the aggregates is said to be the basis of the idea of a living being.
If the aggregates were said to cease in nirvana because they are no longer active, then the remaining aggregates would still exist after nirvana.
Since sentient beings fear the aggregates because they are full of faults, they should not have a sense of peace and security with regard to nirvana.
